concern:
My 2 year program has a cohort of 30 people and I feel like I’m always finding out about gatherings after the fact. Last semester, I consistently saw Snapchat/IG stories and updates on bar hang outs, games, and more literally every week. Sometimes even more. But they were usually during or after the event. I tried to participate but how am I supposed to attend if I had no idea it was happening? And it’d get awkward when I was asking “what’s going on?” or “what are you guys talking about?”. Someone once even said “Poor (my name), she keeps thinking there’s a group chat for this when we plan it spontaneously”. I just get left out because no one tells me. I get that I’m more introverted, but I really do try to talk and participate in conversations and have been mistaken as an extrovert by an extrovert before. I’ve really worked on this over the years. And other introverts in the class somehow also find out about the events, parties, and gatherings. 

Part of me felt ok - I tried to make myself feel better by saying that those people just don’t have a life outside of the program. And that I wanted to have more of a balance. Seeing the same people 5 days a week a day PLUS some evenings and most weekends is a lot! On top of 5-6 classes and student clubs and volunteering, I have a GA position, casual job, serious relationship, family, and other friends to balance. I feel ridiculous and in the minority for feeling this way. 

Now that it’s March, there seems to be less of these events happening second semester, but it still hurts when someone sends a video or picture (e.g. group selfie) to the cohort group text and it’s like almost everybody is in it. This literally happened last night at 2AM for someone’s st patty party. I can’t silent the notifications or not check because sometimes there are important announcements to know. I try to shrug it off and not let it get to me but I feel ashamed that I’ve cried over this before.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! Feel free to share whatever is on your mind or any concerns you might have—I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling a little left out lately, like I'm missing out on things with my cohort. It's been bugging me more than I'd like to admit.
therapist: It sounds like feeling left out is really weighing on you. What would it mean for you to feel more connected with your cohort?

I guess feeling more connected would mean actually knowing about and being included in gatherings. It might mean having more shared experiences and not feeling like I'm constantly on the outside looking in.
Feeling like you're on the outside can be tough. What do you think life would look like if you were more included in these gatherings and experiences?
client: I think I'd feel more like a part of the group, like I really belong. It'd be nice to be in the loop and have those memories to look back on.
therapist: Being in the loop and creating those memories sounds important to you. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding ways to become more involved with your cohort?
client: Honestly, I’d say maybe a 4 or 5. I want to, but it’s hard when I don’t even know where to start or how to change things.
It sounds like you're recognizing a desire to change but feeling unsure about the first steps. What might help you move that confidence from a 4 or 5 to a higher number?

Maybe just figuring out how to get myself in the mix more or finding ways to connect without feeling awkward. Maybe if I could have more one-on-one conversations or find someone who can clue me in on plans.
Building those connections through one-on-one conversations sounds like a meaningful step. What are some ways you might approach these conversations or find someone to help you feel more included?

I guess I could start by reaching out to a couple of people I feel more comfortable with, maybe ask them to grab coffee or something. I could also try to be more active on social media, like commenting on people's posts or stories, to slowly get more involved in their conversations.

It sounds like you have some creative ideas to start fostering those connections. Reaching out to people you feel comfortable with and engaging on social media are great steps. How do you feel about trying these strategies, and do you see any potential challenges?

I feel a bit nervous about putting myself out there, honestly. It's just a little daunting to initiate things when I'm worried about being seen as trying too hard or being intrusive. But I guess it's worth trying if it helps me feel more included.
You’re acknowledging the nerves and recognizing the potential reward of feeling more included. What might make initiating these connections feel a bit easier or more comfortable for you?

Maybe if I had some kind of "in" or shared interest, like a project or a mutual hobby, it might feel more natural to reach out. Or maybe starting with smaller groups rather than diving into the whole cohort at once could take some pressure off.

It sounds like you're considering some thoughtful strategies to ease into these connections. Based on what you've shared, possible options could include identifying a shared interest to discuss or starting with smaller group interactions. What would be a first step you'd feel comfortable trying, and how might you prepare for any challenges that could come up?

I think a first step would be to invite someone for coffee who I know shares a hobby with me, like maybe someone from my class who's also into photography. I could prepare by thinking of some topics to break the ice, so it doesn't feel awkward if the conversation stalls.

That's a great plan. You've put a lot of thought into how to make reaching out feel more comfortable, and it's wonderful to see you taking steps toward building those connections. Inviting someone for coffee who shares your interest in photography sounds like a meaningful way to start. Preparing conversation topics is a smart move to help ease any awkwardness.

Remember, it's perfectly normal to feel nervous, but you're showing courage by taking the initiative. As you navigate this, be kind to yourself. It's all about taking small steps at your own pace. 

Going forward, you might want to explore more shared activities or classes related to your hobbies. This can open up more opportunities for natural interactions. I'll be here to support you as you continue to build these connections and will check in with you to see how things are going. Keep up the great work, and remember you're not alone in this journey.
Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll give the coffee invite a try and see how it goes. It's a bit nerve-wracking, but I'm hopeful.

client: Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling a little left out lately, like I'm missing out on things with my cohort. It's been bugging me more than I'd like to admit.

client: I guess feeling more connected would mean actually knowing about and being included in gatherings. It might mean having more shared experiences and not feeling like I'm constantly on the outside looking in.

therapist: It sounds like you have some creative ideas to start fostering those connections. Reaching out to people you feel comfortable with and engaging on social media are great steps. How do you feel about trying these strategies, and do you see any potential challenges?

therapist: You’re acknowledging the nerves and recognizing the potential reward of feeling more included. What might make initiating these connections feel a bit easier or more comfortable for you?
client: Maybe if I had some kind of "in" or shared interest, like a project or a mutual hobby, it might feel more natural to reach out. Or maybe starting with smaller groups rather than diving into the whole cohort at once could take some pressure off.

Based on what you've shared, possible options could include identifying a shared interest to discuss or starting with smaller group interactions. What would be a first step you'd feel comfortable trying, and how might you prepare for any challenges that could come up?
client: I think a first step would be to invite someone for coffee who I know shares a hobby with me, like maybe someone from my class who's also into photography. I could prepare by thinking of some topics to break the ice, so it doesn't feel awkward if the conversation stalls.
therapist: That's a great plan. You've put a lot of thought into how to make reaching out feel more comfortable, and it's wonderful to see you taking steps toward building those connections. Inviting someone for coffee who shares your interest in photography sounds like a meaningful way to start. Preparing conversation topics is a smart move to help ease any awkwardness.

Remember, it's perfectly normal to feel nervous, but you're showing courage by taking the initiative. As you navigate this, be kind to yourself. It's all about taking small steps at your own pace. 

Going forward, you might want to explore more shared activities or classes related to your hobbies. This can open up more opportunities for natural interactions. I'll be here to support you as you continue to build these connections and will check in with you to see how things are going. Keep up the great work, and remember you're not alone in this journey.
client: Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll give the coffee invite a try and see how it goes. It's a bit nerve-wracking, but I'm hopeful.
